p: A total of 50 informants with knowledge of traditional medicine in the region were approached and interviewed for this study. For the period of the survey, the vast majority of the TMPs encountered were males (96%), whilst females constitute only 2% of the overall data. Culture, religious beliefs, and practices are the socio-cultural factors attributed to gender differences among the practitioners in Nigeria ( Abara, 2012), which are predominantly found in most of the Northern parts of the country. A greater percentage (56%) of the respondents with substantial years of experience in practice are found ranging from 51 – 65 years of age while the least of the respondents found at the age of between 18 – 35 and 66–70 account for 4% and 6%, respectively. Furthermore, the Hausa ethnic group largely account for the highest percentage (66%) of the respondents in the survey followed by the Fulani ethnic group (32%) and both ethnic group specialised mainly in TMP and herbalism ( Table 1).
